thread.title: Bertha contractor plans to ask for more money from state after...
thread.title_full: Bertha contractor plans to ask for more money from state after... | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Bertha contractor plans to ask for more money from state after...
text:
As Seattle Tunnel Partners works to get the tunnel machine Bertha ready to dig again by Christmas, it's also preparing to request more money from the state.
Documents obtained by KIRO 7 through a records request show STP has written to the Washington State Department of Transportation, saying it plans to file a new claim "as soon as possible after the successful resumption of tunneling."
That request will relate to STP's cost for fixing Bertha, which broke down late in 2013.
The process for requesting extra money comes through a change order, which is in all kinds of contracts.
If a house is under renovation, and rot is found in a wall, a change order might be needed, because the work will be more expensive.
The tunnel project is, of course, on a much bigger scale.
The contract is worth $1.3 billion.
According to WSDOT, as of the end of September, STP has requested $227.5 million in change orders, including $125.3 million related to Bertha's breakdown.
But just because contractors ask for extra money doesn't mean they'll get it.
State project administrator Todd Trepanier told legislators Thursday the state has denied $175.1 million of the change orders STP has requested, and that $28.6 million remains under review.
The way the state processes change orders is behind another request for money.
In June, STP asked for more than $6.5 million from the state in interest payments, saying WSDOT has been untimely in processing its requests.
"I think the process has moved a lot slower than we would have liked to have seen it move," STP's Chris Dixon told KIRO 7.
In response, Trepanier said, "I believe that (WSDOT) has been dealing with and proceeding with change orders in the appropriate fashion."
